solving_formula: Competitors â†’ Differentiation â†’ Market Conditions â†’ Strategy
short_answer:
Competitors: Identify who the alternatives are. Direct: same user, same job (direct substitutes). Indirect: different product, same job (alternative solutions). Status quo: Excel, email, manual work, doing nothing. Remember: The real competitor is often the status quo. Map all options users have to solve their problem.

Differentiation: Understand why users choose each option. Price: cost, value proposition, pricing model. Quality / Performance: features, speed, accuracy, reliability. Convenience / UX: ease of use, time to value, user experience. Trust / Brand: reputation, security, established presence. Ecosystem / Lock-in: integrations, network effects, switching costs. Rule: Features don't differentiate â€” reasons do. People don't buy features â€” they buy outcomes. Create a table: Option | Who uses it | Why they choose it | Weakness.

Market Conditions: Assess the market environment. Market size & growth: TAM, SAM, growth rate, maturity. Buyer vs seller power: who has leverage, pricing dynamics. Switching costs: how easy/hard to switch, lock-in factors. Regulation / risk: compliance, legal constraints, regulatory environment. Network effects: yes/no, how strong, winner-take-all dynamics. Competitive intensity: number of players, barriers to entry, differentiation.

Strategy: Define clear positioning and tradeoffs. Compete head-on: match competitors feature-for-feature, price-for-price. Focus on niche: target specific segment, underserved market. Undercut on cost: lower price, better value proposition. Differentiate on UX / trust: better experience, stronger brand. Bundle / unbundle: combine features or focus on core. Remember: Strategy is choosing what not to compete on. If there's no tradeoff, there's no strategy. Output: Clear positioning + tradeoffs. What's our sharp bet? What are we explicitly not doing?
